road  network  for  movement  of  people  and  goods.  The  road 
network  is  vulnerable  because  of  the  mountainous  terrain,  the 
fragile  geological  conditions,  and  the  climate.  The  Government 
and  its  development  partners  have  invested  significantly  in 
improving the road network, but a lack of regular maintenance has 
left the network in a poor condition. There is a need to (i) initiate a 
program  of  regular  maintenance  on  all  HCRN  roads  that  are  in 
good  condition,  and  (ii)  improve  those  HCRN  roads  that  are  in  a 
poor  condition  and  ensure  that  routine  maintenance  begins  on 
these roads as soon as the improvement works are done.  
 
The current NTDP provides a framework of policies and strategies 
for  a  sustainable  road  system  in  PNG.  It  has  led  to  the 
establishment  of 
the  National  Roads  Authority  (NRA)  with 
responsibility  for  maintaining  the  road  network  and  a  road  fund 
financed through road user charges to finance road maintenance. 
The  NRA  and  the  road  fund  are  managed  by  an  independent 
board,  with  representatives  from  road  users,  the  private  sector, 
and the Government. There is a need to translate these initiatives 
into a workable system by (i) strengthening the NRA’s capacity to 
plan  and  manage  road  maintenance  works,  (ii)  seeking  more 
financing for the road fund by rationalizing road user charges, and 
(iii)  awarding  long-term  performance-based  road  maintenance 
contracts.  With  a  functioning  board  and  staff  recruitment  for  the 
NRA  underway,  the  Government  is  keen  to  support  the  MFF.  It 
will  help  to  enable  implementation  of  the  NTDP  and  to  ensure  a 
sustainable  road  system  in  the  Highlands  region.  This  initiative 
could serve as model for other regions of PNG.   
 
The Investment Program will make ports, markets, and livelihood 
opportunities  more  accessible,  and  will  lead  to  savings  in  travel 
time and transport costs. It will enable use of the natural, mineral 
and  human  resources  of  the  Highlands  region  to  be  maximized, 
contributing  to  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Development 
Strategy  (MTDS),  2005–2010  objectives  of  (i)  export-driven 
economic  growth;  (ii)  rural  development  and  poverty  reduction; 
(iv)  promotion  of  sustainable 
(iii)  good  governance;  and 
agriculture, forestry, fisheries, and tourism.

and  capacity  development.  Key  tasks  include  (i)  design  of  road

of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  using  the 
quality- and cost-based selection method.

Road  Maintenance  Funding.  The  NRA  manages  a  road  fund

also  authorized  and  plans  to  collect  road  damage  charges  on

resources  are  needed

Investment  Program  includes  assistance  to  the  NRA  to  prepare 
fresh proposals for the Government to increase road maintenance 
funding. Political support for such proposals will be crucial.

capable  international  and  national  contractors.  The  problem  is

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES  

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
PNG sits between Asia and the Pacific. It comprises the eastern half of the island of New 
Guinea,  together  with  the  island  provinces  of  East  and  West  New  Britain,  New  Ireland,  North 
Solomons (Bougainville) and Manus, and some 600 associated islands. The total land area is 
about  460,000  square  kilometers  (km2)  of  which  only  some  7,300  km2  is  inhibited  by  a 
population of over 6 million. Roads provide the main means of access for most of the mainland 
population  and  road  transport  is  by  far  the  dominant  mode  of  travel.  For  the  island  provinces 
and  some  of  the  mainland  provinces  without  land  connections,  domestic  aviation  and  coastal 
shipping play important roles.  
 
3. 
Economic  growth  in  PNG  is  surging  as  high  oil  and  mineral  prices  boost  Government 
revenues.  Gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  reached  6.2%  in  2007,  about  double  the 
average rate of recent years, and is projected to rise to 6.6% in 2008, before easing to 4.6% in 
2009.  Business  confidence  has  generally  improved,  assisted  by  some  structural  reform  and  a 
relatively stable political environment. Revenue windfalls from the oil and minerals boom have 
greatly  improved  the  overall  fiscal  and  debt  position.  Mining  and  petroleum  revenue  grew  by 
59% in real terms in 2005, by 72% in 2006, and by 15% in 2007. The Government’s total debt 
(domestic and external) has more than halved since 2002 and reached 35% of GDP by the end 
of 2007. It is projected to decline to about 27% of GDP by 2010. The ratio of external debt to 
GDP  of  18%  in  2007  is  well  below  the  30%  maximum  threshold  set  by  the  International 
Monetary  Fund.  By  the  end  of  2007,  savings  from  windfall  revenue  in  trust  accounts  had 
accumulated  to  K2.3  billion  (about  12%  of  GDP  or  $800  million),  providing  an  opportunity  to 
fund maintenance and investment of infrastructure, among other public services.  
 
4. 
The Highlands region comprises five provinces (Chimbu, Enga, Southern, Eastern, and 
Western  Highlands)  and  is  the  country’s  primary  source  of  national  income  and  export 
earnings.1 The  major  gold  reserves  are  in  Enga  and  almost  all  oil  and  gas  production  is  in 
Southern Highlands. The region is also known for its agricultural exports, including coffee, tea, 
and vegetables. About 40% of the PNG population lives in the Highlands region. The terrain is 
rugged,  with  high  mountain  ranges,  steep  valleys  and  fast-flowing  rivers.  The  road  network 
provides a lifeline for exports as well as for supplies to the resource enclaves and the general 
population.  The  Highlands  Highway  and  roads  leading  from  it  form  the  largest  contiguous 
network,  linking  the  Highlands  provinces  with  the  main  port  at  Lae.  However,  high  rainfall, 
seismic activities, fragile geological conditions and a highly dispersed population make the road 
network difficult to develop and sustain.

The road network is classified into national, provincial, and district roads. National roads 
5. 
link  provincial  capitals  and  the  main  population  centers.  The  national  road  network  is  7,600 
kilometers  (km),  of  which  2,600  km  are  sealed  and  the  rest  are  gravel  roads.  Provincial  and 
district  roads  provide  the  secondary  and  tertiary  links  to  the  national  road  network.  Their  total 
length  is  about  10,000  km,  of  which  only  about  1,000  km  are  sealed  and  the  remainder  are 
gravel or unpaved. The traffic volumes on the national highway network are low, except for the 
urban  centers  of  Port  Moresby  and  Lae.  Traffic  on  74%  of  the  national  road  network  is  fewer 
than 500 vehicles per day. Only about 40% of the national road network is considered to be in a 
maintainable condition and the remainder requires some significant rehabilitation, restoration, or 
reconstruction to make the roads usable. Based on the Department of Works (DOW) road asset 
management system (RAMS), the condition of national roads in the Highlands region is poorer 
than the overall national road network. The annual investment in the road sector has averaged 
K500 million over the last 3 years, with a very small proportion spent on maintenance.2   
 
6. 
The  Department  of  Transport  (DOT)  is  responsible  for  national  transport  policy 
formulation, planning, safety, and regulation. The DOW is responsible for carrying out works on 
the  national  road  network.  The  provincial  and  local  governments  are  responsible  for  the 
maintenance  and  development  of  all  provincial and  district roads.  The  provincial  offices  of  the 
DOW  provide  technical  advice  and  support  to  the  provincial  governments.  As  part  of  the 
Government’s  efforts  to  create  autonomous  organizations  to  manage  transport,  the  National 
Roads Authority (NRA) was established in 2003 to take over the responsibility of maintaining the 
national road network, starting with the roads in the Highlands region. In addition, a road fund 
financed from road user charges was created to provide a sustainable source of finance for road 
maintenance. An independent board oversees the functions of the NRA and the use of the road 
fund.  The  11-member  board  comprises  representative  of  the  private  sector  (chamber  of 
commerce), road users (commercial transporters), institutions (engineering and accounting) and 
the  Government  (departments  of  transport,  works,  planning  and  treasury).  To  promote  road 
safety, in 1997 the Government established a National Road Safety Council (NRSC) to advise 
the  Government  on  road  safety  matters,  recommend  road  safety  actions  to  the  appropriate 
authorities,  conduct  educational  campaigns,  and  promote  road  safety  research.  The  14 
members  of  NRSC  include  the  representatives  of  the  departments  of  transport  and  works, 
finance  and  planning,  health,  education,  provincial  and  local  government,  lands  and  physical 
planning,  national  capital  district  commission,  motor  vehicles  insurance  trust,  chamber  of 
commerce, and universities. It is funded from a 5% levy on motor vehicle insurance premiums. 
An analysis of the road sector is in Appendix 2.

Government’s Strategy and Ongoing Efforts 

 
15. 
The  NTDP  provides  a  policy  framework  and  investment  plan  for  road  sector 
development  to  achieve  the  objectives  of  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Development 
Strategy (MTDS), 2005–2010. It prioritizes maintenance and improvement of the existing road 
infrastructure.  The  investment  priorities  in  the  road  sector  are  assigned  to  16  national  road 
corridors,  several  of  which  are  in  the  Highlands  region.  The  NTDP  stresses  the importance  of 
institutional reforms, including enabling the NRA to undertake road maintenance and the NRSC 
to promote road safety.  
 
16. 
The  NTDP’s  overall  aim  is  to  provide  safe  and  dependable  transport  services  to  all 
sections of the community in a cost-efficient and effective manner. Specifically, NTDP plans to 
offer  (i)  better  transport  access  to  education,  health,  and  other  social  services,  especially  for 
rural  communities;  (ii)  more  access  to  production  sites  and  markets  at  lower  transport  costs;  
(iii) better opportunities for raising incomes in remote and impoverished coastal rural areas; and 
(iv) lower transport costs and safer movement of passengers and goods. This will be achieved 
by  (i)  maintaining  and  improving  the  existing  infrastructure  and  services;  (ii)  upgrading, 
rehabilitating  and  improving  infrastructure  that  is  economically  feasible;  and  (iii)  giving  high 
priority to safety and security. Other policy initiatives include (i) new approaches to funding and 
finance,  in  particular  the  introduction  of  road  user  cost  recovery  to  generate  the  required 
revenue for maintenance activities; (ii) promoting stronger partnerships with the private sector; 
(iii)  seeking  a  closer  working  relationship  between  national  and  provincial  governments;  and  
(iv) adopting more integrated and strategic approaches to transport planning, policy formulation 
and decision making. However, implementation of the NTDP has been slow.

23. 
One  of  the  key  lessons  from  past  initiatives  in  the  road  sector  is  the  need  to  ensure 
sustainable  maintenance  before  undertaking  road  development  and  improvement  projects. 
Examples  of  roads  showing  signs  of  deterioration  within  2  years  of  construction  because  of  a 
lack  of  routine  maintenance  are  quite  common  in  the  Highlands  region.  Sustainable 
maintenance  includes  not  only  institutional  arrangements  but,  more  importantly,  a  regular 
source  of  financing  and  delivery  mechanisms.  AusAID’s  Key  Roads  for  Growth  Project 14 
demonstrated the benefits of long-term maintenance contracts that not only ensured good road 
conditions but also provided livelihood opportunities to the roadside communities.   
 
24. 
A  major  barrier  to  development  in  the  Pacific  is  the  lack  of  capacity  in  the  agencies 
responsible for service delivery. PNG is no exception. Road agencies such as the DOW, NRA, 
and the NRSC need to be strengthened and this should complement the ongoing initiatives by 
other development partners, particularly AusAID’s TSSP (para. 20). 
 
Several lessons can be learned from the ongoing ADB projects in the Highlands region:  
25. 
(i)  project  consultants  should  have  direct  responsibility  for  design  and  supervision  rather  than 
playing  an  advisory  role,  (ii)  contract  packages  need  to  be  designed  so  as  to  attract  good 
contractors,15 and (iii) the DOW initiative to acquire rights of way of the national roads should be 
supported. Governance-related lessons are in para. 60.

The NTDP provides a framework of policies and strategies to achieve a sustainable road 
26.

road  network  and  to  a  road  fund  financed  through  road  user  charges  to  finance  road 
maintenance.  The  NRA  and  road  fund  are  managed  by  an  independent  board  with 
representatives  from  road  users,  the  private  sector,  and  the  Government.  There  is  a  need  to 
translate these initiatives into a workable system by (i) strengthening the NRA’s capacity to plan

The  Highlands  region  is  a  major  contributor  to  PNG’s  economy  through  its  agricultural

1. 

Operationalization of the NRA 

 
 
34. 
Inadequate  funding  of  routine  maintenance  is  a  major  cause  of  unsustainable  road 
networks. Failure to perform regular routine maintenance results in a rapid deterioration of roads 
to  the  extent  that  major  rehabilitation  or  reconstruction  is  required.  This  cycle  of  inadequate 
maintenance leading to accelerated deterioration and rehabilitation is self-perpetuating because 
the urgency of repairs to roads that are failing draws funds away from the routine maintenance 
that could have prevented the problem. 
 
35. 
The design of the Investment Program is therefore predicated on providing sustainable 
routine maintenance so that the investment in rehabilitation and upgrading of the project roads 
is not dissipated through neglect. The roads will be managed by an organization whose primary 
focus is road maintenance. Establishment of the NRA is a key institutional policy set out in the 
NDTP.  Details  of  the  NRA  can  be  found  in  Appendix  5.  The  Investment  Program  will  include 
assistance to the newly formed NRA to (i) enable it to take responsibility for managing HCRN, 
and  (ii)  seek  policy  reforms  to  generate  adequate  resources  for  the  road  fund  to  finance 
maintenance. 
  

2. 

Long-Term Maintenance Contracts 

 
Long-term  maintenance  contracts  will  be  an  integral  component  of  the  Investment 
36. 
Program.  For  the  1,400  km  of  the  HCRN  to  be  improved,  the  civil  work  contractors  will  be 
responsible for improving the road and maintaining it to a specified standard for the remainder 
of  a  10-year  contract  period.  The  DOW  will  transfer  responsibility  for  these  roads  to  the  NRA 
once  improvement  works  are  completed.  The  maintenance  contracts  will  be  “performance-
based”  with  fixed  monthly  payments  that  will  be  subject  to  performance  standards  being  met, 
and will include penalties for underperformance. The roadside communities will benefit from the 
livelihood  opportunities  offered  under  these  contracts,  particularly  in  carrying  out  routine 
maintenance tasks such as vegetation control and culvert cleaning (para. 23).   
 
37.

maintainable  will  also  be  included  in  the  Investment  Program,  to  ensure  that  it  does  not 
concentrate only on rehabilitated roads. These roads will be transferred to the NRA and placed

creation  and/or  expansion  of  microenterprises  and  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises.  The 
greater availability, frequency, and reliability and the lower costs of transport services will benefit 
the  public  motor  vehicle  (PMV)  drivers  and  truckers  as  well  as  people  who  rely  on  them. 
Anticipated  social  benefits  include:  (i)  greater  accessibility  to  schools,  leading  to  higher 
enrollments,  fewer  drop-outs,  and  better  academic  performance;  (ii)  better  access  to  health 
care, leading to improved health outcomes; (iii) better access to government services, including 
new  services  such  as  electricity;  (iv)  more  opportunities  to  diversify  and  expand  agricultural 
production,  market  cash  crops,  livestock  and  other  products,  leading  to  higher  household 
incomes and more food security; (v) less dust and better health and living conditions in roadside 
villages;  and  (vi)  more  opportunities  to  travel  easily  and  more  cheaply  for  health,  education, 
social  and  family  reasons  as  well  as  for  livelihood  opportunities.  These  benefits  will  reach 
people living in off-road communities, as well as those immediately adjacent to the rehabilitated 
roads.

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 

The Transport System 

A. 
 
The island nature of Papua New Guinea, together with the absence of land connections 
1. 
between several of the mainland provinces, ensures that domestic aviation and coastal shipping 
play  an  important  role.  The  main  commercial  port  is  Lae,  which  is  the  gateway  for  Morobe 
Province  and  the  Highlands  region,  with  Port  Moresby  as  the  second  main  port.  The  large 
Sepik,  Fly,  and  Ramu  river  systems  provide  access  to  the  interior,  and  there  are  many  small 
ports  of  call  around  the  coast  and  islands  which  provide  the  means  of  access  for  some 
communities.  

Domestic  air  services—operated  by  Air  Niugini—link  Port  Moresby  and  Lae  to  the 
2. 
provincial capitals. Charter and private general aviation services link smaller centers and remote 
inland villages where there are no external connections by road. Air links provided by missions 
to  support  health  centers  and  schools  formed  an  important  part  of  the  early  development  of 
transport within Papua New Guinea, and still retain a significant role today. 

3. 
Road transport is by far the dominant passenger travel mode. The Highlands Highway, 
and roads leading from it, form the largest contiguous network, linking the Highlands provinces 
with  the  main  port  at  Lae.  The  Highlands  Highway  branches  west  of  Mount  Hagen  into  the 
Southern Highlands Highway and Enga Highway. It links to Madang via the Ramu Highway and 
to Popondetta (Morobe province). There are other separate smaller road networks on mainland 
PNG  in  Port  Moresby  (NCD,  Central  and  Gulf  Provinces),  Alotau  (Milne  Bay),  Wewak  (East 
Sepik),  Vanimo  (Sandaun)  and  in  Western  Province,  and  there  are  networks  in  the  island 
provinces radiating out from the provincial capitals. 

B. 

The Road Network and Condition 

4. 
The  road  network  is  classified  into  national,  provincial,  and  district  roads.  There  are 
7,600  km  of  national  roads  under  central  Government  administration  and  funding,  of  which 
2,600  km  are  sealed  and  the  remainder  are  gravel.  Provincial  and  district  roads  are  the 
administrative  and  funding  responsibility  of  provincial  governments.  Their  number  and  total 
length  has  been  changing  as  provinces  create  new  districts  and  designate  existing  tracks  as 
provincial roads. The total length is about 10,000 km, of which only about 1,000 km are sealed. 
The remainder are gravel or earth. 

5. 
National  roads  provide  a  strategic  rural  network,  linking  provinces,  provincial  capitals, 
and other main population centers. National roads are categorized as (i) national routes linking 
population  centers  in  two  or  more  provinces  or  main  roads  traversing  the  entire  length  of  an 
island  province  acting  as  a  collector  road;  (ii)  national  main  roads  linking  major  population 
centers  and  districts  to  national  routes,  or  to  strategically  important  centers  (main  towns, 
harbors, and airports); (iii) national district roads within a single district linking small towns and 
villages  to  centers  within  the  district;  and  (iv)  national  institutional  roads  linking  Government 
institutions  (universities,  defense  establishments,  hospitals)  to  the  national  road  network. 
Provincial  roads  are  categorized  into  provincial  trunk,  district  feeder,  local  access  and  other 
unclassified roads, including private roads and some local town roads. 

Only  about  40%  of  the  national  road  network  is  considered  to  be  in  a  maintainable 
6. 
condition, i.e., the road has not deteriorated to a point beyond which funds can be applied cost- 
effectively to maintain the road to an acceptable standard of service. For the remaining 60% of 
roads, maintenance is confined to minimum emergency repairs to keep the road passable, but

rehabilitation.  About  half  the  network  requires  some  significant  rehabilitation,  restoration,  or

About 30% of the surveyed network is in the Highlands region. Based on data from the 
7. 
Department of Works (DOW) road asset management system (RAMS), the condition of national 
roads is 13% good, 42% fair and 44% poor. The Highlands roads are in a poorer condition than 
national roads in general, with none classed as good and over two thirds classed as poor. 
 
C. 
 
8. 
Traffic  volumes  on  the  national  highway  network,  outside  the  urban  centers  of  Port 
Moresby and Lae, are low. About 74% of the national network (by length) carries fewer than 500 
vehicles a day and 89% fewer than 1,000 vehicles a day. There is even less traffic on provincial 
and  lower-level  networks.  On  the  Highlands  Highway,  which  is  the  main  traffic  artery  for  the 
region, traffic volumes vary between 500 and 2,000 vehicles a day on rural sections, with lower 
volumes across the mountain passes and higher volumes in the more heavily populated valley 
sections. 
 
9. 
Road vehicle registration is carried out at  provincial traffic registries and data reporting 
back to the National Land Transport Board is uneven. The most reliable information on the size 
and  growth  of  the  vehicle  fleet  comes  from  the  number  of  compulsory  third  party  insurance 
policies  taken  out  and  recorded  by  the  Motor  Vehicles  Insurance  Trust  (MVIT).  The  latest 
information  dates  from  2002  and  indicates  a  registered  vehicle  fleet  of  49,000.  However,  the 
accuracy of this figure is unknown and the total is considerably lower than an earlier figure from 
the same source in 1999 of 60,900 vehicles. 
 
D. 
 
10. 
The  Department  of  Transport  (DOT)  is  responsible  for  national  transport  policy 
formulation, planning, safety and the regulation of transport operations. The NLTB implements 
these  policies  in  respect  of  driver  licensing,  vehicle  safety  and  inspection,  licensing  of  heavy 
vehicles  on  interprovincial  routes,  for-hire  transport  and  motor-vehicle  dealerships.  The  DOT’s 
Land Transport Division (LTD) acts as the Board’s secretariat. Provincial land transport boards 
regulate  commercial  passenger  and  goods  transport  within  the  provinces,  although  in  practice 
there is little effective control. Provincial governments are responsible for all vehicle registration 
and LTD attempts to consolidate reports at a national level but in practice the statistics are late, 
incomplete and unreliable, so the number of vehicles operating on the network is not precisely 
known. 
 
The DOW is responsible for management of road maintenance and capital works on the 
11. 
national  road  network  and  provides  some  technical  advice  and  support  to  provincial 
governments. The National Roads Authority (NRA) has assumed maintenance responsibility for 
the first section of the Highlands Highway between Lae and Nadzab, and it is intended that it will 
progressively  take  on  responsibility  for  the  management  of  road  maintenance  delivery  for  all 
national  roads,  starting  with  the  Highlands  region.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  and  National 
Planning  (MFNP)  is  responsible  for  physical  and  economic  planning  at  national  level  and  for 
approval of the budget requests from the line agencies. It administers some minor parts of the 
road  program  directly,  in  particular  the  District  Road  Improvement  Program.  Interagency  and 
private sector communications and consultation on land transport matters are facilitated by the 
Transport Sector Coordination, Monitoring and Implementation Committee.

Road Funding and Investment 

Provincial  governments  are  responsible  for  the  maintenance  and  development  of  all 
12. 
provincial  roads.  Their  technical  and  administrative  capacity  to  carry  out  this  task  varies  and 
some  provinces  rely  on  the  provincial  arms  of  the  DOW  for  assistance,  through  formal  or 
informal  agreements.  In  a  few  cases,  where  the  DOW  has  been  unable  to  fund  adequate 
upkeep  of  national  roads  of  importance  to  particular  provinces,  the  provinces  have  provided 
maintenance support. 
 
13. 
The National Road Safety Council (NRSC) is a semi-independent body that coordinates 
and  promotes  road  safety.  It  was  set  up  in  1999  and  is  chaired  by  DOT,  but  its  membership 
includes representatives of concerned government and private agencies. It is funded from a 5% 
levy on compulsory motor vehicle third-party insurance premiums.  
 
E. 
 
14. 
The present system of national road funding is in several parts: (i) the majority of funding 
is  through  annual  budget  submissions  by  the  DOW  to  MFNP,  appropriation  of  the  agreed 
allocation  through  the  national  budget,  and  disbursement  to  the  DOW  against  warrants  for 
specific items of expenditure; (ii) the NRA receives a direct operating allocation from the budget 
and can draw monies from the newly created road fund against its road maintenance program; 
(iii)  provincial  governments  receive  a  budget  allocation  from  central  government  and  they  are 
free  to  allocate  this  against  provincial  programs,  including  provincial  roads;  (iv)  individual 
government  ministers  receive  allocations  for  expenditure  within  their  electoral  districts,  part  of 
which may go to provincial roads; and (v) some private companies receive tax credits in return 
for funding maintenance of certain road sections, mainly on roads essential for access to the oil 
and gas fields and metal mining. 
 
15. 
Investment in the road sector has averaged K500 million per year over the last 3 years. 
Of this, 15% has been spent on road upgrading, 56% on rehabilitation and replacement, 21% on 
maintenance  (routine,  periodic,  and  emergency),  and  6%  on  operations  (road  safety,  policing) 
and  administration.  Forward  expenditure  for  2008  is  at  a  similar  level,  but  direct  central 
government  expenditure  on  the  road  sector  is  projected  to  reduce  to  K150  million  a  year  by 
2012 as current donor-assisted programs end.  
 
F. 
 
16. 
The Government’s strategy for the transport sector is designed to achieve the objectives 
of  the  Medium-Term  Development  Strategy  (MTDS)  and  is  set  out  in  the  National  Transport 
Development Plan (NTDP) Update, 2006–2010. The NTDP is in two parts, the first addresses 
sector  policy  and  institutional  development  and  the  second  the  infrastructure  investment 
program.  The  NTDP’s  overall  aim  is  “to  provide  safe  and  dependable  transport  services  to  all 
sections  of  the  community  in  PNG  in  a  cost-efficient  and  effective  manner.”  The  NTDP  vision 
includes: (i) better transport access to education, health and other rural welfare and government 
services, and increased personal mobility, for all persons in the community at all times; (ii) better 
transport  access  to  production  sites  and  markets,  at  lower  transport  cost;  (iii)  enhanced 
opportunities  for  raising  income  levels  in  remote  and  impoverished  coastal  rural  areas;  and  
(iv) lower transport costs and safer cargo and passenger movements. 
 
17. 
To  achieve  this  aim  in  the  road  sector,  the  strategy  will  (i)  maintain  and  improve  the 
existing  infrastructure  and  services;  (ii)  upgrade,  rehabilitate  and  carry  out  new  construction 
works only where economically feasible; and (iii) conduct business on "safety and security first" 
basis.  NTDP  proposes  to  raise  funds  directly  from  road  users  and  to  deposit  revenues  into  a

The  road  investment  plan  identified  16  priority  sections  of  the  national  highway  for

Porgera-Togoba  Road.  The  Government  also  has  a  district  road  improvement  program 
administered  by  the  Department  of  National  Planning  intended  to  fulfill  a  community  service 
obligation for roads that do not justify development on strict economic criteria. 
 
G. 
 
Public  passenger  transport  is  provided  by  passenger  motor  vehicles  (PMVs),  mainly 
20. 
vans  and  small  buses  of  12  to  30  seats,  operated  on  a  route  licensing  system.  In  2004,  from 
insurance records, there were about 5,300 registered PMVs in the country, of which some 1,300 
were in NCD, 1,000 in Lae, and 2,000 in the Highlands. There were about 1,100 taxis, almost all 
in Port Moresby.  
 
21. 
The largest urban PMV network is in Port Moresby, which has a planned route structure, 
although  this  has  not  been  reviewed  for  some  years.  Regulatory  enforcement  is  weak, 
deviations from routes and service schedules are common, and some of the 24 routes are no 
longer operating.  
 
22. 
Passenger fares are regulated and fares are increased on receipt of submissions from 
the operators and after taking account of cost increases indicated by a PMV and taxi cost model 
operated  by  the  NLTB.  Regulation  of  fares  is  undertaken  by  the  Independent  Consumer  and 
Competition  Commission  (ICCC),  which  recently  undertook  a  comprehensive  review  of  PMV 
and taxi costs and fare structures and set a new fare determination and review process for the 
next 5 years.1  
 
23.  Market entry and inter-provincial routes served are regulated for “hire-or-reward” goods 
transport, with a focus on the Highlands Highway. Tariffs are lodged annually with the DOT or 
its appointed agent and a minimum 60-day notice of intended increases is required, with public 
rights  of  objection  and  official  determination.  Government  policy  is  to  replace  the  existing 
quantity-licensing system with a quality-based licensing system.  This would require operators to 
show  that  they  have  appropriate  managerial  expertise,  business  experience,  and  financial 
backing before they are granted an operating license.

Road Safety 

Overloading of goods vehicles is one of the factors blamed for the rapid deterioration of 
24. 
Highlands  roads,  and  for  the  network  in  general.  An  axle  load  survey  found  that  15%  of 
commercial  vehicles  on  the  Highlands  Highway  in  Morobe  province  were  overloaded 
contributing  to  significant  damages  to  the  roads.  The  maximum  recorded  vehicle  weight 
exceeded the maximum allowable vehicle weight of 42 tons by 10 tons (24%). 
  
25.  Many of the bridges in the Highlands are Bailey bridges, and while most appear to be in 
good  condition,  some  are  cause  for  concern  at  higher  loads.  Bridge  failures  caused  by 
oversized loads have occurred on the provincial network. One reason for the failure to enforce 
load limits arises from the division of responsibility between agencies. The power for performing 
axle  load  testing  rests  with  the  DOT.  However,  the  NRA  is  seeking  to  have  the  legislation 
changed  to  improve  effectiveness  and  is  in  the  process  of  installing  a  weighbridge  on  the 
Highlands Highway near Lae. Further weighbridges at Goroka and between Mount Hagen and 
Togoba  (the  junction  between  the  Enga  and  Southern  Highlands  Highways)  have  also  been 
proposed. 
 
H. 
 
26.  While  there  is  a  complete  absence  of  up-to-date  statistical  data,  the  road  crash  and 
injury rates for Papua New Guinea are estimated to be one of the highest in the Pacific region, if 
not the highest. Data from 2002 indicate a road fatality rate of 40 per 10,000 registered vehicles, 
four  times  higher  than  for  the  Fiji  Islands  and  40  times  higher  than  the  best  performing 
countries.  The  main  causes  of  traffic  accidents  are  drunk  driving,  inadequate  road  safety 
awareness  by  drivers  and  pedestrians,  an  absence  of  uniform  traffic  engineering  standards, 
hazardous roads, and inadequate enforcement of traffic rules. 
 
ADB provided technical assistance (TA)2 from 1984 to 1996. The TA established a road 
27. 
accident  reporting  and  analysis  system  within  the  LTD,  was  instrumental  in  setting  up  NRSC, 
and undertook accident black spot and remedial treatment analysis and staff training. While the 
NRSC  continues  to  operate  and  has  recently  been  revitalized  under  new  management,  the 
computer system for accident data analysis was lost in a fire that destroyed DOT’s headquarters 
office in the late 1990s. Since then, the NRSC has effectively taken over the lead role in road 
safety  from  the  LTD.  It  funds  small  projects  to  educate  the  community  in  road  safety,  raise 
standards of traffic enforcement and bring stakeholders together to tackle the issues. It plans to 
expand into vehicle safety enforcement and to reestablish a basic traffic accident database from 
several years of accumulated police accident records. Road safety has yet to be fully instituted 
across the road sector agencies; in particular, the DOW has not introduced an effective safety 
audit function into its design procedures, and no agency is carrying out hazard identification and 
safety management across the road network.

B. 

Functions and Responsibilities 

The  Government’s  decision  to  establish  the  NRA 1  led  quickly  to  the  drafting  and 
2.

April 2004.2 
 
The  objectives  of  the  NRA  as  recorded  in  the  act 3  are  (i)  to  raise  funds  for  the 
3.

maintenance  programmes;  and  (iii)  to  ensure  that  all  routine,  periodic  and  emergency

The  purpose  is  to  optimize  the  contribution  of  road  assets  to  the  economic  and  social 
development of PNG. 
 
4.

for  road  maintenance  works,  
(iv)  monitoring  and  inspecting  the  executed  works  to  ensure  their  compliance  with  quality

13. 
It is intended that funds for NRA road maintenance programs will ultimately come wholly

operate a road fund to be funded primarily from road user charges. The road fund will be used

14. 
The principal reasons for establishing such a road fund are: (i) to secure a more reliable 
and sustainable level of funding for road maintenance than has been available from government 
budgetary allocations, which have been subject to funding shortfalls and annual variations; (ii) to 
protect  funds  raised  from  road  user  charges  against  raids  on  those  funds  for  use  on  other 
purposes;  (iii)  to  establish  a  close  fee-for-service  link  between  the  charges  paid  by  users  and 
the road maintenance service received by users; (iv) to provide a lever to secure more efficient, 
cost-effective  and  customer-responsive  road  sector  management;  and  (v)  to  allow  users 
themselves  to  have  a  greater  say  in  how  road  maintenance  funds  are  managed.  A  properly 
established and operating road fund is considered a prerequisite to the successful operation of 
the NRA.

consumption levels (which can be expected to increase as vehicle usage increases, along with 
a growing domestic economy), the volatility of international oil prices, the national economy, and 
similar considerations.

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  

The Government of Papua New Guinea (PNG) has adopted the Medium-Term Development Strategy (MTDS), 
2005–2010  as  its  strategic  framework  to  promote  national  development.  The  overarching  goal  of  the  MTDS  is 
export-driven  economic  growth,  rural  development  and  poverty  reduction,  including  through  good  governance 
and  the  promotion  of  sustainable  agriculture,  forestry,  fisheries,  and  tourism.  The  strategy  will  be  realized  by 
empowering  Papua  New  Guineans,  especially  those  in  rural  areas,  to  mobilize  their  own  resources  for  higher 
living  standards.  The  key  priorities  for  the  period  to  2010  are  (i)  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  of  transport 
infrastructure,  (ii)  promotion  of  income-earning  opportunities,  (iii)  basic  education  and  adult  education,  (iv) 
primary  health  care  and  HIV  prevention,  and  (v)  law  and  justice.  In  the  transport  sector,  rehabilitation  of  the 
Highlands Highway is one of the Government’s top priorities. 

The  purpose of  the  Asian Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  country  strategy  and  program  in  PNG,  2006−2010,  is  to 
help the Government meet its MTDS goals. ADB and the Government have agreed that the strategic areas that 
clearly satisfy the principles and lessons are: (i) public financial management, (ii) private sector development, (iii) 
the transport sector, and (iv) health and HIV.

1.  Key Issues  

In rural PNG, most people have land: in the Highlands region, an extended family or sub-clan may have up to 3–
5 hectares of productive land divided into 10 or more small gardens that are used to cultivate a range of food and 
cash  crops.  Households  are  generally  able  to  grow  food  to  meet  basic  household  consumption  needs;  of  the 
households  surveyed  for  the  Highlands  Region  Road  Improvement  Investment  Program,  more  than  70%  had 
sufficient food in their gardens for 3 months or more. A small household coffee garden may generate K500 from 
annual  sales.  Rural  people  also  have  extensive  family  and  clan  networks  to  assist  them  in  times  of  need. 
Nonetheless, and particularly as people’s livelihoods are increasingly linked to a cash economy, there are wide 
discrepancies in the well-being of different segments of society. In addition to low incomes, a 2001 participatory 
poverty assessment (funded by ADB) clearly indicated the non-income dimensions of poverty: specifically, people 
considered  they  were  poor  when  they  lacked  (i)  jobs,  (ii)  land,  (iii)  education,  (iv)  services  such  as  health  and 
water, and (v) transport and roads. The most pressing needs were safe drinking water and usable roads. While 
available  data  are  limited  and  need  to  be  updated,  the  risks  of  rapidly  rising  poverty  levels  in  PNG  are  clear. 
Salient issues include the following.

2. Design Features 

 

 

 

The Investment Program incorporates several strategies to facilitate the ability of communities and households to 
realize  benefits  from  road  improvements  and  maintenance  and,  thereby,  to  reduce  poverty  in  the  Highlands 
region. The Investment Program design includes (i) priorities for employment of local men and women for road 
rehabilitation  and  maintenance,  (ii)  contractor  specifications  for  provision  of  HIV  awareness  and  prevention 
programs  in  construction  camps  and  neighboring  communities,  and  (iii)  an  extensive  community  relations  and 
participation  program  linked  to  different  aspects  of  subproject  preparation  and  implementation.  The  Investment 
Program  includes  a  community  empowerment  project  to  be  funded  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction 
(JFPR),  which  will  (i)  incorporate  a  participatory  approach  into  the  preparation  and  implementation  of  the 
Program,  (ii)  assist  communities  to  initiate  strategies  to  strengthen  the  social  and  economic  benefits  of  road 
improvements, and (iii) promote equitable benefits for all gender and social groups.   

The  community  empowerment  project  will  include  components  aimed  at:  (i)  supporting  the  rehabilitation  and 
maintenance  of  social  infrastructure  in  roadside  villages  adjacent  to  the  Investment  Program  roads; 
(ii)  developing  skills  of  rural  women  through  agricultural  extension,  alternative  livelihood  and  micro-enterprise 
training; (iii) raising community awareness and gender-responsive behavior changes on health (with an emphasis 
on  sexually  transmitted  infections  [STI]  and  HIV),  violence  against  women  and  road  safety;  (iv)  pilot-testing 
initiatives aimed at ensuring women’s equal access to safe transportation services. All activities will be carried out 
in consultation with relevant district administration and in line with relevant provincial and/or district development 
plans. 

A. Findings of Social Analysis 

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

The primary beneficiaries of the Investment Program are the approximately 2 million people who live and work in 
the Highlands region. They include the following groups of road users: (i) households living in communities along 
and in the vicinity of the rehabilitated and maintained roads, who grow and sell a range of food and cash crops; 
(ii) drivers of public motor vehicles (PMVs) that provide a range of passenger and goods transport services, and 
commercial  truck  drivers;  and  (iii)  businesses  in  the  Highlands  region  including  vendors  at  local,  informal 
markets, trade store owners, coffee and other buyers and small and medium-sized enterprises in provincial and 
district  towns.  National,  provincial  and  local  authorities  also  benefit  from  and  are  instrumental  for  the 
implementation of road improvements and, particularly, the ongoing maintenance of roads. 
Project 1 includes 220 km of roads to be upgraded. The 2010 population in the road influence zonea of Project 1 
roads is estimated at 400,000 (projected to reach 900,000 by 2025). About 225,000 people live west of Project 1 
roads  in  Southern  Highlands  province  (projected  to  double  by  2025).  The  principal  linguistic  and  tribal  groups 
include  the  Huli  and  Duna  in  western  SHP;  people  belonging  to  Angal  and  other  Mendi-speaking  groups  in 
central Southern Highlands province; and, Enga-speakers and Ipili in Enga province. All these tribal groups have 
(i)  clan-based,  patriarchal  social  structures;  (ii)  complex  systems  of  social  and  other  exchanges  (wantok);  (iii) 
strong  attachment  to  land  owned  collectively;  (iv)  community  leaders  who  are  chosen  on  the  basis  of 
achievements rather than heredity; (v) a highly developed system of dispute resolution that is based on notions of 
reparations and payback that often leads to tribal conflicts and fighting; and (vi) a rigid duality of gender whereby 
women are subordinate to men. 

Throughout the Highlands, people live on their clan territory, in dispersed homesteads or small hamlets of 4–10 
closely related households. An extended family of 10–15 adults and their children will generally have at least 2–3 
hectares and, up to 5 hectares of agricultural land. Since the upgrading of portions of the Highlands Highway and 
feeder  roads,  slightly  larger  villages  have  been  established  adjacent  to  the  roads.  Household  size  in  these 
villages  tends  to  be  larger  (9–18  persons).  Men  outnumber  women  and  nearly  all  households  are  headed  by 
men. The level of social development is low throughout the Highlands region. Adult literacy ranges from about 
10%  to  40%;  rates  for  women  are  significantly  lower  than  for  men.  The  proportion  of  school-age  children 
attending school is estimated at less than 50%. Health indicators are generally low throughout PNG, particularly 
in rural areas. HIV has reached general epidemic proportions in PNG, with 87% of HIV positive people living in

People living in the Highlands walk to most destinations. Every day, women walk up to several hours to reach 
their gardens; daily or several times a week, they walk similar distances to sell at local markets. They are often 
carrying heavy loads as well as children. Children walk up to 4 hours per day to go to school, and health centers 
are often several hours’ walk from a village. The use of PMVs and other transport is generally limited to longer 
trips; e.g., men going to district or provincial towns, secondary students going to towns to attend school and men 
and  women  who  are  traveling  to  visit  family.  Market  vendors  do  not  use  transport  to  reach  regional  markets 
because  the  costs  often  exceed  the  anticipated  revenues;  in  addition,  many  PMV  drivers  will  not  carry  goods. 
Women  use  PMV  services  much  less  than  men,  in  part  because  of  their  concerns  about  being  robbed  and/or 
assaulted when they travel. 

Livelihoods  in  the  Highlands  region  combine  subsistence  agriculture  (sweet  potatoes),  cash  cropping  (coffee 
and—at  higher  altitudes—Irish  potato  and  pyrethrum)  and  raising  livestock  (pigs  and  chicken).  The  agricultural 
inputs are limited and the yields low. Some men operate “walkabout” sawmills and harvest bamboo to make mats 
used  as  house  walls.  Marketing  of  surplus  food  crops,  cash  crops  and  livestock  is  done  by  women,  selling  to 
buyers  or  through  direct  sales  at  local  markets  located  at  villages  and  PMV  stops  along  the  roads.  Access  to 
regional  markets  or  factories  is  limited.  Local  market  sales  also  include  cooked  food  for  travelers,  handicrafts 
(bags and hats) and the resale of betel nuts and cigarettes that have been transported from coastal areas. Wage 
employment is limited to a small number of teachers or aid post orderlies in local communities or to towns, where 
more people obtain paid work in small businesses. The rate of job-related migration is high. Urban unemployment 
rates are very high (e.g., 38% for men) and many men in rural villages are without work. 

Household  incomes  from  sales  of  agricultural  products  or  other  local  market  sales  are  generally  very  small. 
Households in communities along Project 1 roads may earn up to K500 a year from sales of coffee; and, up to 
K1,000 a year from the sale of small livestock. The average daily revenues of surveyed market vendors ranged 
from K24 to K50. In surveys along Project 1 roads, households were asked several questions about their level of 
well-being: 45% of households eat meat or fish once a month or not at all; 35%, once a week or less; and, 20% 
more  often.  About  70%  of  households  have  food  stocks  in  their  gardens  to  last  3  months  or  longer.  Asked  to 
assess their situation, just over 50% say they have just enough to meet household needs; about 35% say they 
are poor because they do not have enough to meet needs; and, 15% consider themselves to be well-off.

Gender and Development 

 

Tribes  in  the  Highlands  are  patriarchal  societies,  with  traditional  roles  of  men  and  women  rigidly  defined.  The 
primary roles of women are to bear children and to nurture the family. Women’s work is to raise children, collect 
water and firewood, and grow and provide food for their families. In the gardens, women do most of the planting, 
weeding  and  harvesting;  they  provide  45–70%  of  the  agricultural  labor  for  food  cropping,  and  make  significant 
contributions  to  coffee  gardens  and  other  cash  crops. As the rural economy focuses more on cash crops and

villages  to  look  for  wage  employment,  women  must  take  over  their  responsibilities  for  preparing  gardens,  or 
negotiate  with  male  relatives  for  assistance.  As  more  and  more  children  are  in  school,  the  family  labor  pool

In rural areas, more than three quarters of women are engaged in agricultural activities such as cultivating food 
and  cash  crops  and  raising  small  livestock.  They  generate  cash  incomes  from  the  sale  of  cash  crops  and  the 
local  marketing  of  small  surpluses  of  food  crops  and  livestock.  Women  walk  long  distances  every  day,  to  and 
from their gardens, to and from local markets, to and from sources of drinking water. When they make these trips, 
they are generally carrying heavy loads, including sweet potatoes and other produce from their gardens that they 
are carrying home and/or to the market, as well as their children. Women and children also tend to walk when 
they  are  going  to  schools  and  health  care  facilities.  In  general,  women  do  not  use  PMV  or  other  transport 
services. The daily trips to and from gardens do not require public transport. PMV and other transport services 
are  often  not  available  and/or  services  to  health  care  facilities,  markets,  coffee  factories  and  towns  that  are 
beyond  walking  distance  are  infrequent.  PMV  drivers  often  provide  only  passenger  services  and  do  not  allow 
people to transport goods to market. The passenger fares and costs to transport goods mean that transporting 
goods to market is often not economically viable. For  women, the use of public transport can be unsafe, since 
they are often victims of robbery and assaults including rape. 

The health status of PNG women is poor, despite some improvements in recent years. The current fertility rate is 
high at 4.3 (compared to 6.1 in the 1970s). However, the high maternal mortality ratio of 370 deaths per 100,000 
live  births  has  remained  unchanged.  Women’s  physical  health  is  compromised  by  problems  associated  with 
excessive workloads, poor nutrition and lack of access to safe water. Domestic violence causes physical injury 
and  increases  levels  of  stress  and  anxiety.  Chronic  sickness  is  often  regarded  as  a  “natural”  part  of  being  a 
woman in PNG. Based on available data from 1987 to 2005, the incidence of HIV in women aged 15–24 years 
was 2–3 times higher than among men in this age group; the incidence of HIV continues to be significantly higher 
among women than among men in the 25–29 age group. The gender impacts of HIV mean that when women get 
infected  and  become  sick,  it  not  only  affects  them  but  has  serious  consequences  for  households  and 
communities in PNG.

acquiring  use  rights  for  additional  land,  as  well  as  for  paying  compensation  for  damage  to

the  planning,  implementation,  and  monitoring  of  land  activities  to  improve  roads,  including 
preparation of the subprojects and resettlement plans and all consultations.  
 
HRMG will monitor and report twice a year to DOW and ADB on all activities associated 
8. 
with  the  MOA  and  payment  of  compensation  to  affected  persons.  HRMG’s  monitoring  will 
include: (i) compliance with agreed policies and procedures; (ii) prompt approval, allocation and 
disbursements  of  funds  and  payment  of  compensation  to  affected  persons,  including 
supplemental  compensation  for  additional  and/or  unforeseen  losses;  (iii)  availability  of  other 
resources  and  efficient,  effective  use  of  these  resources;  and  (iv)  requirements  for  remedial 
actions. 
 
HRMG  will  recruit  an  independent  monitoring  organization  to  conduct  external 
9. 
monitoring  for  the  subprojects.  The  monitoring  organization  will  be  recruited  and  mobilized  at

HRMG, the DOW, and ADB on all activities related to additional land requirements, community 
consultations, preparation of resettlement plans, payment of compensation, and social impacts.  
 
10. 
The  key  consultations  will  occur  before  and/or  as  part  of  (i)  the  screening  and 
preparation of the subsequent projects, (ii) the MOA negotiation and carrying out of the detailed

resettlement plan, and (iv) the land investigation and preparation of land investigation reports for 
to  establish  the  public  road  reserve.  Disclosure  of  the  resettlement  plan  will  comply  with  the 
ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2005). 
 
11. 
Grievance redress mechanisms will be established to ensure that all grievances on any 
aspect of land acquisition and/or compensation for affected assets are resolved in a timely and 
satisfactory  manner.  The  mechanisms  will  be  based  on  the  provisions  of  the  Land  Disputes 
Settlement  Act.  As  a  first  step,  traditional  local  mediation  will  be  used,  using  appointed  and 
traditional leaders. In the event of grievances that cannot be resolved through local mediation, 
the matter will be referred to the land court system.

the  HRMG  to  build  (i)  understanding  of  government  policies  and  procedures  for  acquisition  of

subproject areas, staff of the office of the Valuer General and any other organizations involved
